title: 103_hr2396
content: The Act titled "Child Support Enforcement Improvements Act of 1993" allows depository institutions to provide financial records to state child support enforcement agencies without liability. The Act allows depository institutions to disclose financial records to state child support enforcement agencies without liability. State agencies can only use the information for establishing, modifying, or enforcing child support obligations. Individuals can seek civil damages against a state for unauthorized disclosure by its officers or employees. Individuals can bring a civil action for damages against a State for unauthorized disclosure of financial records. No liability if disclosure was made in good faith but erroneously interpreted. Damages awarded include $1,000 for each unauthorized disclosure or actual damages sustained by the plaintiff. The section outlines the calculation of damages for unauthorized disclosure, including actual damages, punitive damages for willful disclosure or gross negligence, and the costs of the action. Definitions for "depository institution" are also provided. The term "financial record" is defined by the Right to Financial Privacy Act of 1978. The term "State child support enforcement agency" refers to a State agency that administers child support obligations. State child support enforcement agencies have access to and can use consumer reports in child support cases. State child support enforcement agencies can access consumer reports for establishing, modifying, or enforcing child support obligations if paternity is established or acknowledged by the consumer according to state laws. The agency must provide written notice to the consumer before obtaining the report and certify that all requirements have been met. Additionally, the term 'State child support enforcement agency' is defined as a State agency administering a program for child support obligations. SEC. 4. HEALTH CARE SUPPORT. The text discusses the inclusion of health care coverage in child support orders as mandated by the Social Security Act. It outlines procedures for ensuring coverage of health care costs for children in accordance with state guidelines and expediting the resolution of noncompliance allegations. The Social Security Act mandates the inclusion of health care coverage in child support orders. States must establish guidelines for covering health care costs for children in these orders, meeting minimum standards set by the Secretary. Regulations will outline the contents of these orders to streamline the process and address noncompliance issues. The paragraph outlines the requirements for covering health care costs of children in child support orders, including order contents, responsibility distribution, insurance provision, denial circumstances, penalties for noncompliance, and adjustments for changing parental circumstances. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must develop guidelines for covering health care costs in child support orders, considering the child's best interests, parents' financial circumstances, and cost-effectiveness. Regulations to implement these guidelines must be issued within 9 months of the Act's enactment. Health and Human Services will issue proposed regulations to implement amendments within 14 months of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will issue final regulations within the same timeframe. The inclusion in the Incentive Payments Program of dependent health insurance provided due to successful enforcement is outlined, considering the collection of support from absent parents. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will prescribe regulations within 6 months to implement the amendment regarding the enforcement of support obligations for noncustodial parents to pay for and obtain medical insurance coverage for children. A study will also be conducted to determine incentives for states to enforce these obligations. Services will conduct a study to determine incentives for states to enforce noncustodial parents' obligations to pay for children's health and dental expenses. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must report the study results to the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee within 12 months. SEC. 5. ANNUAL REPORTS ON STATE COMPLIANCE WITH CHILD SUPPORT TIME LIMITS. Amends the Social Security Act to include compliance standards for states. SEC. 6. EMPLOYERS MUST WITHHOLD WAGES FOR CHILD SUPPORT PAYMENTS. Employers must pay child support obligations to the state within 10 days, with penalties for late payments. Amendment to the Social Security Act requires employers to pay child support obligations within 10 days, with a $1,000 penalty for late payments. Penalties collected must be used for the state plan approved under section 454. Effective immediately upon enactment, applicable to wages paid thereafter. The amendments made by this section of the Act require immediate compliance for employers to pay child support obligations within 10 days, with penalties for late payments. State plans approved under section 454 must meet these additional requirements, with a grace period for states needing legislation. State plans approved under section 454 must meet additional requirements before the 1st day of the 1st calendar quarter following the close of the 1st regular session of the State legislature after the enactment of this Act. Each year of a 2-year legislative session is considered a separate regular session. SEC. 7. NATIONAL PARENT LOCATOR NETWORK. The Social Security Act is amended to expand the Parent Locator Service, establishing a national network for child support enforcement across states. This network allows states to locate absent parents, access records from other states and federal sources, and determine if there are multiple child support orders for the same parent. The Parent Locator Service is expanded under the Social Security Act to create a national network for child support enforcement. This network allows states to access files from other states and federal sources to locate absent parents and identify multiple child support orders. The network also provides for quick processing of locate requests and ensures information is readily accessible to courts through computer terminals.
